Ten Stages and Ten Practices
First, the Stage of Joy.
In the south there is a country called Three Eyes, where there is a bhiká¹£u named Good Vision.
The meaning of south is as explained before.

The country called Three Eyes illustrates the Dharma eye, wisdom eye, and insight eye. This good and wise advisor always uses these three eyes to skillfully benefit sentient beings in this practice, thus called Three Eyes.
Eyes means vision.
Using the Dharma eye to illuminate and purify, one always sees the Dharma body;ğŸ”½Using the wisdom eye to know faculties, one skillfully understands the capacities of beings;
Using the insight eye to discern, one clearly sees what is right and wrong.
Using these three eyes, one practices without confusion.
If one lacks these three eyes, one will always be deluded oneself, and nothing will be unstained. How can one benefit others and help them leave behind the entanglements of afflictions?
The good and wise advisor's way of virtue and practice is used to name the country, called Three Eyes.
The bhiká¹£u named Good Vision uses these three eyes to know the faculties, and in accordance with the faculties bestows benefits without vainly teaching, which is called good vision.
Why is the bhiká¹£u placed at the beginning of these ten practices?
It is to clarify that in practicing the stages, one first uses the three eyes to illuminate, and in the midst of the world, one is free from defilements, and is called a bhiká¹£u.
Because the bhiká¹£u is unstained, this is the meaning of liberation.
The bhiká¹£u at the beginning of these ten practices is the meaning of practicing the stages without being stained.

The bhiká¹£u Virtuous Cloud on the peak of Mount Marvelous in the beginning of the ten abodes is to clarify that arising from samÄdhi and observing is the meaning of the end of characteristics and emerging from the mundane.

In the beginning of the ten grounds, the perfumer named Blue Lotus Flower clarifies that those whose minds often turn back from entanglements should enter saá¹ƒsÄra to accomplish the practice of great compassion, and while dwelling in the world, know the truth and are not defiled, so he is called Blue Lotus Flower.
Using the secular to illustrate it, it is like the style of VimalakÄ«rti.

The first ground is with the night spirit Vasanta-mati, which means mastering spring growth, to illustrate the great compassion practices of the ten grounds, always dwelling in the long night of birth and death, mastering all sentient beings, causing the sprouts of goodness to grow.
It is also the spirit of spring growth that masters the seedlings.
When Sudhana reached the country of Trilocana, he searched everywhere in the cities, towns, villages, markets, river sources, mountains, and valleys, in all places. City can be understood.
Neighbor is said in the Great Commentary of the Shangshu: Five families form a neighborhood, three neighborhoods form a group, three groups form a village, five villages form a town.
This is the system of Yu and Xia.
The rest can be understood.
Sudhana's search in this way illustrates observing all dharmas, stillness and disturbance, without essence, without attachment in any place.
The bhiká¹£u walking back and forth in the forest illustrates the myriad practices like a forest, providing shade and adorning the myriad existences.
The land has the adornment of forests, the true realm; people have the adornment of practice, adorning themselves and benefiting others.
The one who goes back and forth in the sutra clarifies the essence not abiding in birth and death, not abiding in liberation and nirvana.

Therefore, the bhiká¹£u in his prime, in order to clarify being in the world without being swayed by praise or blame, and benefiting beings without end, is in his prime, with a handsome and upright appearance that is delightful.

His hair is dark blue, curling to the right without disorder, with a fleshy protrusion on the top of his head, skin the color of gold, three lines on his neck, forehead broad and flat, eyes long and wide like blue lotus flowers. In this way, the thirty-two marks are complete, clarifying the inner adornment of the Dharma eye, wisdom eye, and insight eye, and the outer manifestation of good conduct. With compassion and joy, knowing the faculties and connecting with beings, he attains the marks of recompense adorning the body, fully possessing the thirty-two marks, which are the true fruits of recompense.

When he is walking properly, he is neither slow nor fast, and he walks with care. Countless devas, nÄgas, the eight classes of beings, Åšakra, BrahmÄ, the world-protectors, and the ten assemblies surround him in front and behind. This is because the assembly that receives his teachings is attracted by his practice.

The directional gods turn with the directions. The two directions above and below - Zhen, Xun, Li, Kun, Dui, Qian, Kan, and Gen - are the ten directions. There are gods in each direction that follow and turn as he walks.
It also represents the Dharma. Zhen is wood. Wood contains the Dharma of the ten directions. The ten below and eight form the character wood.
Zhen is sound, vibration, the blue dragon, good fortune, spring growth, illumination, and the head of many virtues. Using this Dharma, the east is the head.
The south is Li, which is emptiness, correctness, the sun, the eyes, the mind, literature, and flourishing brightness.
If one understands the mind to be empty, then one will have wisdom, literature, and brightness.
Therefore, asking one and knowing ten is the meaning of the flourishing of wisdom.
Using these ten to ask one and know ten illustrates the brightness of wisdom.
The north is Kan, water, Xuanwu, and the beginning of brightness.

This direction takes the initial division of light and darkness as the character bei. Therefore, in the eleventh month, one yang arises, indicating the beginning of the division of light and darkness. Darkness departs and light comes, with light and darkness facing each other.

It also represents being in the midst of Xuanwu, the state of confusion, ignorance, and evil. Goodness and evil are not in harmony, and there is no trust or obedience. It is also the lack of comparison between light and darkness, all opposing each other, so it is called the character bei.
On the back of Bhiká¹£u HÇi-dÄƒng, two vehicles emerge to illustrate it.
Moreover, Kan is solid and is water. Water benefits myriad things, all of which are the meaning of turning with the direction.
The way of good and evil exists in the ten directions.
Northeast is for mountains, stones, stopping, young men, and children.
The beginning of the year and the end of the year are in the middle of this, with the clash of the chous and wuyi, which is the boundary between yin and yang.
The tomb of metal is in the chou, and the tomb of wood is in the wei. The sun is born in the yin, and the moon is born in the shen.
Using geng to represent mountains, it shows that mountains are high and difficult to climb.
Using renba to represent the geng character.
If it represents the difficulty of ascending the Way of the Sage, with a pure and still mind like a mountain, then the correct Way will appear.
Using geng to stop the mind, with the correct Way appearing as the meaning of geng, all are the meaning of turning according to the direction.
Southeast is for xun, wind, the eldest daughter, speech, and wind teaching, so xun governs the xin chou and xin wei.
Using chou as young men and wei as the multitude, it is for faith and obedience.
It clarifies that xun is for speech and wind teaching, transforming the multitude.

The ignorant and young boys who have reached the Way, their virtue accords with Heaven and Earth, and they do not need teaching. Therefore, the mouth emits wind and bestows verbal teachings to determine right and wrong.
Right and wrong are exhausted, and speech is all-encompassing, so the two all-encompassing together form the character Xun.
The summary is like this.

The Dharma of the ten directions is difficult to measure, and the Dharma of one direction possesses the ten directions. The mutual differences in essence are difficult to fully explain. It simply follows worldly Dharma and the Dharma beyond the world, and turns with the events.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra says, The deity of the cardinal direction follows the cardinal direction, and turning is the Dharma.
This clarifies that the Dharma has no fixed essence, and changes with the events.
This clarifies that within this position, according to the affairs of the world, the teaching and practice are free, turning with the direction.
Leading in front clarifies that skillfully bestowing the teaching and practice leads all sentient beings, with the teaching and practice as the priority.
The foot-walking spirit holds a jeweled lotus flower to support its feet. The spirit represents wisdom, abiding in the world without defilement in the midst of myriad practices.
This clarifies that the essence of practice is free from defilements.
The JambÅ«dhvaja forest spirit rains various flower clouds.
This forest is near Lake Anavatapta, symbolizing myriad practices as a forest, providing shade and protection for sentient beings.
Without practicing a single practice, abiding in immeasurable practices, liberating sentient beings.
Flowers represent practice.
The inexhaustible light spirit emits light to dispel darkness, always using wisdom to break through all deluded darkness.
The immovable treasury earth spirit manifests various treasure stores, enabling all sentient beings to cultivate wholesome karma and give rise to the treasure store of wisdom.

The all-illuminating sky spirit adorns the sky, using the wisdom of universal illumination to deliver sentient beings, universally enabling sentient beings to practice sky-like conduct, breaking through all delusions and darkness, and attaining immeasurable blessings and virtues to adorn and accomplish themselves.
The virtue ocean spirit rains maá¹‡i jewels, because with great compassion and kindness, it purifies the defilements of sentient beings.

The Sumeru mountain spirit of the treasury of non-defilement bows in respect, bending the body and joining palms, to show that one's own wisdom is lofty and excellent, yet one always practices humility and respect, without a mind of arrogance.
The unobstructed power wind spirit rains wonderful incense and flowers.
This is the spirit of theå·½ direction, which shows that wisdom and skillful teaching are like the wind, and those who hear it rejoice, which is the meaning of incense and flowers.
The å·½ direction represents the meaning of wind and teaching.
The spring harmony night spirit adorns its body and bows to the ground, as the practice of myriad good deeds is the adornment.
All means that practice is never apart from the ground of fundamental wisdom, always awakened.
The day spirit holds a maá¹‡i banner that universally illuminates all directions and abides in the sky.
Emitting great light shows that the formless dharma body is like space, and the light of fundamental wisdom is the essence of the maá¹‡i jewel banner.

Using the pure light of wisdom as the essence of illumination, it illuminates myriad practices and mind and objects. Always using the fundamental universal light wisdom to universally illuminate the ten directions, without a single dharma to be attained, yet using myriad practices to liberate sentient beings, not apart from this wisdom.
Always not confused about mind and objects, one is then able to be unattached to the world.
Dwelling in the world to teach and transform sentient beings, always practicing these ten kinds of conduct without fault.
These ten deities illustrate the practice of spiritual wisdom dwelling in the world and the ten perfections, causing practitioners to emulate them.
I have heard that the holy one... and below is the request for the Dharma.
The bhiká¹£u replies:
Although I am young and have recently left the household life clarifies that he initially followed the ten abodes and newly entered the head of the ten practices.

In this life, I have cultivated pure conduct in the presence of thirty-eight Ganges river sands of Buddhas, which clarifies that I have not been apart from the three dharmas of the Dharma eye, wisdom eye, and insight eye for thirty eons. These three dharmas are all able to eradicate the ten ignorances above the mind, objects, and consciousness.ğŸ”½Because all minds, objects, and consciousnesses observed by these three dharmas are not apart from what is known and seen by the Dharma eye, wisdom eye, and insight eye, they are always in accord with the practice of the eightfold correct path, and therefore it is said that I have cultivated pure conduct in the presence of thirty-eight Ganges river sands of Buddhas.

Because the ten thousand afflictions of wrong views are all observed with the three eyes, there is not a single dharma that is not liberated, because they are not apart from what is known and seen by the Dharma eye, wisdom eye, and insight eye, because there is not a single dharma that is not pure, and because body, speech, and mind are all pure, it is said that I have cultivated pure conduct in the presence of thirty-eight Ganges river sands of Buddhas.
With the three eyes purified, all seen, heard, sensed, and cognized objects are universally pure, which is called the Buddha's knowledge and vision.

The sÅ«tra says, In some Buddhas' places, for one day and night, they purely cultivated chaste conduct, up to seven days and nights, half a month, a month, a year, up to inexpressibly many eons, purely cultivating chaste conduct, up to entering the place of no realization to purely cultivate chaste conduct. They also saw those Buddhas attaining perfect enlightenment, expounding the Dharma with each having distinctions, without confusion. This is because the moon has no beginning or end, no root or branch. Above all mental objects, they do not see a single dharma that is right or wrong, subject or object, which is cultivating chaste conduct.
Chaste means pure.

Skillfully understanding the nature of mind and objects without defilement, purity, right or wrong, always contemplating in this way, this is purely cultivating chaste conduct in all Buddhas' places. Because one's own mind and objects are all pure, this is being a Buddha.
Practitioners should never, on the basis of self and other, hold to this and establish that as wrong, and attain Buddhahood.
Even if one diligently labors for eons, one cannot escape birth and death.
How is it that the mind and realm are both pure?
Using the three eyes as appropriate, one upholds the world.
Practitioners should always observe the world with the three eyes, causing the mind, realm, and consciousness to become the wisdom-karma.
With the pure mind and realm, compassion and joy, one guides sentient beings without weariness.
What need is there for worry?
All Buddha-dharmas will naturally become clear.
I only know this bodhisattva's liberation door of the inexhaustible lamp... below this, it clarifies pushing merit forward, further causing one to advance.

Using the Dharma eye, wisdom eye, and discernment eye to always illuminate what is present, causing one not to be confused about the mind and realm, then the seeds of emotional consciousness are completely gone, and only wisdom appears, called the liberation door of the inexhaustible lamp.
Moreover, if one lamp is used to light a hundred thousand lamps, the darkness is all illuminated, and the light never ends. Therefore, it is called the lamp of the inexhaustible.
In this stage, the perfection of giving is the primary practice, and the other nine are the accompanying practices.
Second, the practice of benefiting.
In the south, there is a country called Famous.
The meaning of south is as explained above.

As for the country being called Famous, it illustrates that the wisdom and virtue of the youth Vimalagarbha are lofty and far-reaching, and there is nothing that is not understood. He thoroughly understands all the worldly methods that benefit life, such as writing, counting, mathematics, and various skills. For this reason, his fame is widely known, and thus the country is called Famous.

As for the youth being named Vimalagarbha, because the youth has attained the life of immortality, all worldly phenomena cannot obstruct or destroy him. He manifests his form according to the capacities of beings within birth and death, and is thus called Vimalagarbha.
As for being on an island in the river, a place in the water that is habitable, a large one is called a continent, a small one is called an island, and a small island is called a sandbar.
Playing with sand illustrates the method of calculation, knowing the number of grains according to the amount of sand collected.

In this stage, the child freely knows the Dharma. There are approximately ten dharmas: writing, calculation, seals, medicine, crafts, compounding immortal elixirs, agriculture, commerce, physiognomy, and teaching according to people's capacities. With these ten dharmas, one benefits sentient beings.
The calculation method of ayuta is one myriad in this land.
Nayuta is one hundred million in this land.
The rest of the calculations have not been translated from the Sanskrit text.
From I only know this skillful means and spiritual powers below, it is the promotion of virtue.
In this stage, the perfection of precepts is the main practice, and the other nine are the accompanying practices.
The stage of the ten abodes takes the observation of the twelve links of dependent origination, the ocean of birth and death, as the ocean of Buddha's wisdom as the essence of precepts.
These ten practices are the essence of precepts, which form the practice of benefiting others.
The third practice of non-opposition takes the perfection of patience as the main practice, with the other nine as companions.
The meaning of south is as before.
There is a great city called Abiding in the Ocean. The previous two stages refer to a country, while this stage refers to a city. Why is this clarified?

It is simply because the knowledge and virtue of the previous stages are referred to as a country, while this stage emphasizes the practice of patience to guard against arrogance in body, speech, and mind, and is therefore called a city.
The city is called Abiding in the Ocean to illustrate that the mind of humility is like the ocean, accommodating all streams without rejection.
The upÄsikÄ named PÅ«rá¹‡a is able to fully possess giving, precepts, patience, diligence, and compassion. Possessing these five dharmas is called PÅ«rá¹‡a.
Residing in this city refers to the inner adornment of the practice of patience, not dwelling externally, and thus being in the city.
The house adorned with immeasurable various treasures on all four sides illustrates that inwardly embracing the Dharma-endurance in the one mind evokes the adornment of immeasurable merits.
The upÄsikÄ sitting on a jeweled seat uses endurance as the essence of the seat, with youthful beauty and upright delight, illustrating the adornment of endurance's rewards.
Wearing plain clothes with loose hair, the body without necklaces, illustrates the abandonment of external adornments to clarify the appearance of endurance.
The color, appearance, majestic virtue, and radiance illustrate that the aspiration and virtue of the practice of endurance evokes the delightful countenance.

The house is vast, with a single room opening to four doors, illustrating that the generosity and kindness of endurance are vast, with the four means of conversion and the four immeasurables being limitless.

Placing a small vessel in front of the seat, the food for the immeasurable great assembly coming from all worlds is obtained according to their faculties, with the attainment of the Way being each different.
Using the patience of the Dharma, giving, precepts, kindness, compassion, humility, and being free from arrogance and conceit is the small vessel, and the merit and virtue are vast and boundless.
If one can be patient with a mind like empty space, the merit and virtue will be inexhaustible.

Therefore, the verse says: Practicing patience with no middle or edge in body and mind, eliminating views of size like empty space, the mind is equal, without high or low, and the ten dusts of Dharma giving are also inexhaustible.
This stage clarifies the patience of the ten practices. The ten thousand maidens generally clarify the practice of being patient, gentle, and pleasant, using women to represent it.
Having a retinue of a million asaá¹ƒkhyeyas clarifies that the practice of being patient, kind, compassionate, and gentle is complete.

From I only know this liberation of the bodhisattva's inexhaustible treasury of merit and virtue onward, it clarifies promoting virtue and progress, using the single gate of patience to clarify that all practices are complete and all treasuries of merit and virtue are complete.
The fourth is the practice of being unyielding, with the perfection of diligence as the main practice and the other nine as companions.
The meaning of south is as before.
The city named Great Prosperity illustrates the perfection of diligence.
Greatly promoting the practices of the two kinds of giving of wealth and Dharma, it is all-pervasive, so the city is named Great Prosperity.
The householder named Clear Wisdom uses wisdom to accord with worldly customs, skillfully practicing the two kinds of giving to benefit all sentient beings, so he is named Clear Wisdom.
Sudhana was on a jeweled terrace in the market square of the city, sitting on a seat adorned with countless treasures, with ten kinds of adornments, as extensively explained in the sutra.
They are all born from the fruition of the ten kinds of perfections.
First, it is said that the jeweled terrace is the essence of the seat, illustrating that the myriad practices take the seven factors of enlightenment as their essence.

The seven factors of awakening are: 1. the factor of awakening of investigation of phenomena, 2. the factor of awakening of energy, 3. the factor of awakening of mindfulness, 4. the factor of awakening of joy, 5. the factor of awakening of tranquility, 6. the factor of awakening of concentration, 7. the factor of awakening of equanimity.
Taking the fundamental wisdom as the body of the elder, he is therefore the wise one.
The householder is one who abides in the world without being defiled, and is thus called a householder.
With his wisdom, he sits in the seven factors of awakening, accomplishing immeasurable wonderful practices, and performs the practices of benefiting oneself and benefiting others.

Clearly understanding all myriad practices and contemplations, he treats habitual delusions, diligently persevering without weariness, and accomplishes great compassion and great kindness, all without leaving the fundamental essence of the wisdom of the emptiness of all dharmas, the purity of self-nature, and the wisdom of non-action.

Using the superior and inferior of the perfuming of defilement and purity, and the mind that delights in transcending the world, to make one know the obstacles of the decrease and increase of compassion that are not complete, establishing the names of the practices of ascending to the ten abodes, ten practices, ten dedications, ten grounds, and the two stages of equal and wondrous, serving as a model for practitioners, causing learners to emulate them and not err in accordance with the teachings.

Therefore, sitting on a jeweled terrace in the middle of the crossroads, using the seven factors of enlightenment as the body of the seat, to clarify the four means of conversion and the four immeasurables, it is called the crossroads.
Using the seven factors of enlightenment to subsume the ten pÄramitÄs and immeasurable practices, it is called adorned with myriad treasures.
Always dwelling in birth and death and afflictions is like the bustling marketplace.
It clarifies that the practices of diligence at this stage should be carried out in the way of the two kinds of giving of wealth and Dharma.
Sudhana requested the Dharma, and the layman had him observe the immeasurable multitude of various colors and the different desires of the multitude that came.

After contemplating this, the householder momentarily focused his attention and looked up into the sky. As needed, everything descended from the sky and satisfied the entire great assembly. This illustrates that the essence of wisdom is emptiness, and all karmic rewards are born from the illusory wisdom of emptiness.
Looking up at the sky in this way illustrates that the ocean of merit and virtue born from the illusory wisdom of emptiness arises from this wisdom of emptiness.
Therefore, contemplating its source, it causes one to know the causes that give rise to karmic rewards and merit.

Great compassion, the wealth of Dharma, and great abandonment all arise from the wisdom of emptiness. All myriad practices are born from the wisdom of emptiness, as well as all sentient beings and karmic fruits.
It causes practitioners to skillfully understand that all merits and rewards, as well as the causes and effects practiced by all sentient beings, all exist due to the wisdom of emptiness.
Sentient beings do not understand this and mistakenly create ignorance, performing good and evil karma, confused about the wisdom of emptiness, and transmigrating in birth and death.

Those who understand this attain the great wisdom of illumination and always follow worldly customs, practicing compassion, the ocean of merits and virtues, and the two kinds of giving of Dharma and wealth, vast and inexhaustible, arriving according to thought, because they arise from this wisdom of emptiness.

Therefore, it is necessary to contemplate and make learners recognize the basis and follow it, being unstained in practice, like a lotus flower that is delightful to behold while remaining unstained by the water it grows in.

In the fourth perfection of diligence among the ten abodes, it is with the elder Megha in the marketplace, speaking the Dharma door of the adornment of wheel letters for the sake of ten thousand people, causing them to study the worldly wisdom that knows the world, understand worldly names, phrases, and the meanings of letters, and all the names mutually giving rise to each other, each and every name having all other names, mutually forming and arising, with the fundamental nature being nonexistent.

Now, in the Ten Grounds, the fourth is the practice of being unyielding, practicing the perfection of diligence, to clarify that the householder Zhi lived in the market and on the streets, demonstrating the four means of conversion, practicing the two kinds of giving of wealth and Dharma to convert sentient beings, born from the wisdom of emptiness.
The rest of the extensive meaning is fully clarified in the sÅ«tra.
From I only know this liberation of the mind that gives rise to the treasury of blessings and virtues and below, it clarifies the promotion of virtue.
The fifth is the practice of being free from delusion and confusion, with the perfection of meditation as the main practice and the other nine as companions.
The meaning of south is as before.

The great city named Lion's Palace clarifies that meditative concentration can give rise to great wisdom, and in the midst of birth and death and the great assembly, one can decisively destroy the dharma of birth and death and attain fearlessness, thus it is called Lion's Palace.
It clarifies that this wisdom does not come from relying on others externally, but is manifested by the stillness of one's own mind, thus it is called Lion's Palace.
Wisdom is the lion.

Sudhana saw the elder RatnacÅ«á¸a in the market, which clarifies that this stage does not dwell in the essence of meditation, but in the midst of the confusion of birth and death, guiding and accepting all sentient beings.

Therefore, the elder took Sudhana's hand and brought him to his dwelling, showing him the house, which was made of genuine gold, with walls of white silver, a hall of crystal, and towers of lapis lazuli, pillars of beautiful shell, and adorned all around with a million kinds of jewels. There was a lion throne of red pearls and maá¹‡i jewels, with maá¹‡i for the eaves and pearls for the net covering above.
The agate treasure pools were filled with fragrant water, and countless jeweled trees were arranged in rows all around.
The house was vast, with ten stories and eight gates.

Sudhana observed them in order. This is because the essence of meditation, great wisdom, merit, and the fruition of the eightfold correct practices are born from causes. Observing the fruition, one knows the causes.
Sudhana observed the house of karmic retribution, the causes and effects, and immediately attained the path he cultivated.

The treatise author's verse says: The mind of meditation is pure and bright, the intrinsic nature is spotless like true gold, vast and penetrating like space without boundaries, this is the house of the wise.
The eye of wisdom universally observes all dharmas, pure and spotless without middle or edge, all dharmas cannot be grasped or abandoned, this is the wise one's surrounding wall.

Understanding that the nature of the objects of form is originally non-existent, the mind king skillfully governs it as the hall, pure wisdom clearly sees and illuminates the world, universally illuminating the dharmas is the pavilion.
Always in all seeing and hearing, always without grasping or abandoning, without tilting or moving, able to see and hear all forms and sounds, not hearing in the heard is the jeweled pillar.

The nature of the objects of form is originally without nature, the wise one takes it as the essence of the seat, able to sit in the ten directions of the dust and afflictions, sitting as great wisdom without defilement.
Attaining great wisdom and fearlessness, this is the lion seat of the wise.
Skillfully setting up the net of teachings to filter sentient beings, the mind is always pure, filled with fragrant water.
The pavilion has ten stories and eight gates, the ten perfections and eight right practices are its conduct.

In the lowest story, one gives food and drink, in the second, one gives the precious robe of precepts, in the third, the precious garland of patience, in the fourth, the woman of loving-kindness, compassion, and diligence, in the fifth, the wonderful adornments of meditation and wisdom, the bodhisattvas of the five grounds dwell in the illumination of the supernormal powers, in the sixth, the wonderful vehicle of pure wisdom and emptiness, the bodhisattvas of the sixth ground dwell therein.

On the seventh level, skillful means dwells in birth and death, on the eighth level, effortless wisdom is sovereign, on the ninth level, the Dharma king of the one-lifetime bodhisattva resides, on the tenth level, the fruition of Buddhahood is completely filled.

Thus, one practices and studies in sequence, ultimately without beginning, middle, or end, using this samÄdhi, wisdom, and dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gate, abiding in sovereign wisdom that is neither empty nor existent.
Sudhana said:
What good roots did you plant to obtain such karmic rewards?
The elder said:
Good man!

I recall that in the past, more eons ago than atoms in a buddha-land, there was a world called Perfect Adornment, and a buddha named Boundless Light, Dharma Realm, Universal Adornment King TathÄgata, Arhat, Samyak-Saá¹ƒbuddha, replete with the ten titles.
When that buddha entered the city, I played music and burned a ball of incense as an offering.

I dedicated this merit to three places: to forever leave behind all poverty and suffering, to always see buddhas and good and wise advisors, and to always hear the true Dharma. Therefore, I obtained this reward.
The commentary says:
More eons ago than atoms in a buddha-land means that while deluded, one has not yet awakened to the eons of dust.
There was a world called Perfect Adornment clarifies that the fundamental universal bright wisdom has a world of boundless merits and virtues.

The Buddha's name is Boundless Light, King of Universal Adornments of the Dharma Realm, which is the fundamental universal bright knowledge itself, eternally illuminating the dharma realm and the realm of space, shared by all sentient beings, but due to delusion, the fruits of retribution in the three realms and six paths are not the same.

If for a single thought one accords with the unconditioned, uncontrived meditation of the innate true nature, the nature of all mental objects and forms is inherently undefiled, and one attains universal bright knowledge.

It is inherently without support, not relying on emptiness or existence, yet it can universally illuminate the wondrous functions of the ten dharma realms and the dharma realm, adorned with boundless virtues.
But it is separated from the fundamental essence by delusion, and is not apart from ignorance, greed, and anger.

A single thought of pure mind, deluded and unawakened, with great wisdom appearing before one, but using the fifty Dharma gates of the ten abodes, ten practices, ten dedications, ten grounds, and equal enlightenment to harmonize and mature wisdom and compassion, forming the practices of Samantabhadra.

However, the essence of wisdom is not apart from the initial mind. Time does not change, and wisdom does not alter. It only causes the spiritual functions of wisdom and compassion to gradually increase and expand, gradually increasing in brightness, causing them to be vast and penetrating, with a magnitude equal to empty space, pervading the Dharma realm equally, being the same as the minds of all sentient beings, abiding in all sentient beings, appearing according to their minds, and being able to universally respond to the worlds of the ten directions, reaching everywhere.
From beginning to end, it is like this. The intrinsic nature is always so, without the thought of performing spiritual powers or transformations.
By the power of the roots of goodness of compassion, it is naturally always so, and the practice of merit is fulfilled.
This Elder RatnacÅ«á¸a, with the meditation of the nature of all forms being unconditioned, developed this universal light wisdom and manifested the teaching and transforming of all sentient beings.

But when deluded, it is said to be the eons of the buddha lands' dust motes. Once awakened, the past and present are all nonexistent. Progressing without leaving, within the timeless there is gradualness, like clouds in the sky. Without leaving the empty essence, there is gathering and dispersing. However, the empty essence is not included in time.
